awd_titl_txt: CICI: RDP: Supporting Controlled Unclassified Information with a Campus Awareness and Risk Management Framework
awd_abstract_narration:
Protecting Controlled Unclassified Information (CUI) is mandated by the executive order 13356, and today is required for research in sectors such as defense and aerospace. Regulatory requirements for research will increase, with CUI regulations covering categories including Agriculture, Financial, Legal Records, and Business information. When combined with existing regulations already seen by universities, such as HIPAA, and the European Union's GDPR, a well-defined and consistent framework for working with regulated data is critical for institutions of higher education. This project describes a cost-effective ecosystem (REED+) to manage regulated data that meets the compliance requirements found in a campus environment.  

The REED+ framework integrates NIST SP 800-171 and other related NIST publications as the foundation of the framework. This framework serves as a standard for campus IT to align with security regulations and best practices, and create a single process for intake, contracting, and facilitate easy mapping of controlled research to CI resources for the sponsored programs office, human subjects office, and export control office. The framework allows researchers to experience faster intake of new funded projects and be more competitive for research dollars. Using student-developed training materials and instruction, researchers, administrators, and campus IT are now able to more clearly understand previously complicated data security regulations affecting research projects. The ecosystem developed from this project enables new partnerships with government agencies, and industry partners from the defense, aerospace, and life science sectors. Experiences and best practices in providing cyberinfrastructure and security awareness developed from this collaboration are documented and shared with the broader CI and campus community through conferences, journals and workshop.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This funded project followed the principles of risk management and integrated the NIST SP 800-171 framework with the campus infrastructure to protect a common type of regulated research found in many institutions: Controlled and Unclassed Information (CUI).  The project mapped out the processes involved with CUI researchers, sponsored program offices, human subject office, export control office and computing infrastructure resources from a unit ownership perspective. This helped all the roles involved, see where hand-offs were happening and do local process improvement.  The project developed many training materials to educate researchers and scientists on regulations and cybersecurity practices. This helped them to understand and handle data to meet the regulatory requirements.  The workflow developed from this project empowered the campus IT to refine their policies and procedures on Data Security by aligning with NIST SP 800-171. The success of the project laid out the groundwork to support future requirements handling additional regulated research and CUI. A collection of templates was developed and shared to help campus IT to meet various regulatory requirements. The project involved participation from both the undergraduate students and graduate students. By pairing students with staff mentors and area expertise, this project helped prepared the students with real-world problem-solving skills as they joined the workforce. The impact of this project is evidenced by the CUI workshop series. 155 participants from 84 different institutions participated the workshops in 2020 and 2021. A whitepaper on campus CUI was published and is well-received by the community. The product developed by this project is current shared as a resource with 245 institutions from community colleges through R1 institutions.
